item.title: Collatz Conjecture
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

I think this forum needs a new rule,

Don’t post unless it is:
a) useful
b) relevant
c) realistic

read over your post before send it,
check Google first, make sure what you post isn’t complete bullshit.

It is starting to aggravate me, frank_ obviously has more of a knack for sorting out idiots, kudos.

Read full topic

item.title: Collatz Conjecture
item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

[b]4.7.4 The StackMapTable Attribute[/b]

The StackMapTable attribute is a variable-length attribute in the attributes table
of a Code (§4.7.3) attribute. This attribute is used during the process of verification
by typechecking (§4.10.1).

A StackMapTable attribute consists of zero or more stack map frames. Each
stack map frame specifies (either explicitly or implicitly) a bytecode offset, the
verification types (§4.10.1) for the local variables, and the verification types for
the operand stack.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @eczema3 eczema3
item.description:
@eczema3 wrote:

[quote=“R3volution`, post:12, topic:333073”][quote author=eczema3 link=topic=429492.msg3154093#msg3154093 date=1268854120]

I’m cool

public int collatz(int input) { int iterations = 0; for (; input > 1; iterations++) { input = (input % 2 == 0) ? input / 2 : 3 * input + 1; } return iterations; }

So I heard you cant even correctly implement a for loop?

So i heard you were you were wrong and the loop works as it should.
[/quote]

So I heard your sentence is wrong.[/quote]

So I heard- wait yeah, my sentence is wrong.
